hints_html:
The right Riemann sum for the function \(f(x)\) is:

\(R_n=\sum_{i=1}^nf(x_i)\Delta x\)
hints_latex:
The right Riemann sum for the function $f(x)$ is:

$R_n=\sum_{i=1}^nf(x_i)\Delta x$
hints_raw:
The right Riemann sum for the function <math> f(x) </math> is:

<math>
R_n=\sum_{i=1}^nf(x_i)\Delta x
</math>
sols_html:
The interval has size 1 so \(\Delta x=\frac{1}{n}\). The interval is \([0,1]\) so \(x_i=\frac{i}{n}\). In this case \(f(x)=6-3x^2\) so the right Riemann sum is:

\[\begin{aligned} R_n&=\sum_{i=1}^n(6-3(\frac{i}{n})^2)(\frac{1}{n})\\ &=\frac{6}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n1-\frac{3}{n^3}\sum_{i=1}^ni^2\\ &=\frac{6}{n}(n)-\frac{3}{n^3}\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\\ &=6-\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{2n^3}\end{aligned}\]

So the integral is:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx&=\lim_{n\to \infty} R_n\\ &=\lim_{n \to \infty}(6-\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{2n^3})\\ &=6-\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{2n^3+3n^2+n}{2n^3}\\ &=6-\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{2+3/n+1/n^2}{2}\\ &=6-\frac{2-0-0}{2}=6-1=5\end{aligned}\]

Checking our answer, we see that

\(\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx = (6x - x^{3})\mid_{0}^{1} = 6(1)-(1)^{3} - (6(0)-(0)^{3}) = 6-1 =5\)

which matches the above.
sols_latex:
The interval has size 1 so $\Delta x=\frac{1}{n}$. The interval is
$[0,1]$ so $x_i=\frac{i}{n}$. In this case $f(x)=6-3x^2$ so the right
Riemann sum is:

\begin{align*}
R_n&=\sum_{i=1}^n(6-3(\frac{i}{n})^2)(\frac{1}{n})\\
&=\frac{6}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n1-\frac{3}{n^3}\sum_{i=1}^ni^2\\
&=\frac{6}{n}(n)-\frac{3}{n^3}\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\\
&=6-\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{2n^3}
\end{align*}

So the integral is:

\begin{align*}
\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx&=\lim_{n\to \infty} R_n\\
&=\lim_{n \to \infty}(6-\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{2n^3})\\
&=6-\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{2n^3+3n^2+n}{2n^3}\\
&=6-\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{2+3/n+1/n^2}{2}\\
&=6-\frac{2-0-0}{2}=6-1=5
\end{align*}

Checking our answer, we see that

$\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx = (6x - x^{3})\mid_{0}^{1} = 6(1)-(1)^{3} - (6(0)-(0)^{3}) = 6-1 =5$

which matches the above.
sols_raw:
The interval has size 1 so <math> \Delta x=\frac{1}{n} </math>. The interval is <math> [0,1] </math> so <math> x_i=\frac{i}{n} </math>. In this case <math> f(x)=6-3x^2 </math> so the right Riemann sum is:

<math>
\begin{align}
R_n&=\sum_{i=1}^n(6-3(\frac{i}{n})^2)(\frac{1}{n})\\
&=\frac{6}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n1-\frac{3}{n^3}\sum_{i=1}^ni^2\\
&=\frac{6}{n}(n)-\frac{3}{n^3}\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\\
&=6-\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{2n^3}
\end{align}
</math>

So the integral is:

<math>
\begin{align}
\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx&=\lim_{n\to \infty} R_n\\
&=\lim_{n \to \infty}(6-\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{2n^3})\\
&=6-\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{2n^3+3n^2+n}{2n^3}\\
&=6-\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{2+3/n+1/n^2}{2}\\
&=6-\frac{2-0-0}{2}=6-1=5
\end{align}
</math>

Checking our answer, we see that

<math>
\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx = (6x - x^{3})\mid_{0}^{1} = 6(1)-(1)^{3} - (6(0)-(0)^{3}) = 6-1 =5
</math>

which matches the above.
statement_html:
Evaluate \(\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx\) by computing the limit of the right-endpoint Riemann sums \(R_n\) as \(n\rightarrow\infty\).
You may use the formula \(\sum_{i=1}^{n}i^{2}=n(n+1)(2n+1)/6\).
No credit will be given for computing this integral using antidifferentiation, although you may use antidifferentiation to check your answer.
statement_latex:
Evaluate $\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx$ by computing the limit of the
right-endpoint Riemann sums $R_n$ as $n\rightarrow\infty$.\\You may use
the formula $\sum_{i=1}^{n}i^{2}=n(n+1)(2n+1)/6$.\\\emph{No credit will
be given for computing this integral using antidifferentiation, although
you may use antidifferentiation to check your answer.}
statement_raw:
Evaluate <math>\int_0^1(6-3x^2)dx</math> by computing the limit of the right-endpoint Riemann sums <math>R_n</math> as <math>n\rightarrow\infty</math>. <br />
You may use the formula <math>\sum_{i=1}^{n}i^{2}=n(n+1)(2n+1)/6</math>. <br />
''No credit will be given for computing this integral using antidifferentiation, although you may use antidifferentiation to check your answer.''
